For Release PMs Tuesday, Dec. 19
Developing The Savings Habit
DOC.TEXT: Subtle advertising, constant sales, periodic discounts and rebates, and an abundance of consumer goods helped make big spenders of many Americans in the decade of the 1980s. Now, as if the abundance of choices were insufficient, ordinary folks are likely to be presented with still another decision in the 1990s: They will be asked to decide between spending and saving. It won't be easy after a 15-year addiction to the retail marketplace, a period in which the subtle arts of marketing, along with plentiful credit and tax incentives, helped produce a live-for-now mentality. Uncle Sam will be trying to break that habit in the 1990s, and the government is preparing the first of its incentives, a Family Savings Account that would allow $5,000 a year to be saved tax-free. That's a big incentive, but one many Americans will find difficult to exploit because, as envisioned, those savings would lose their tax exemption if not maintained for a decade, an eternity for those used to immediate gratification. In this and other ways the Bush administration hopes to accomplish two ends: Promote savings, which are necessary for industrial development and job creation, and spur Americans to seek greater financial rewards by investing for the long term. The consequences are enormous for individuals, the general economy and government. For individuals, saving for the long term rather than immediate spending might provide the means to buy even more tomorrow. Investments grow; the value of purchases often falls. Money saved generally means a sounder economy, since it is invested in research and development of plant and equipment that in turn enhance productive efficiency _ more goods at lower cost _ and create jobs. For government the return might not be immediate. In fact, tax exemptions can have the short-term effect of reducing revenues. But over the longer term, a larger, healthier economy inevitably means an increase in revenues. Whether the goals can be accomplished is made uncertain by many factors. For one thing, the Family Savings Plan would involve a 10-year period of time, an ambitious endeavor in a nation accustomed to making tax changes each year. Individual Retirement Accounts, for example, were originally meant to spur savings by allowing $2,000 a year to be invested and deducted from current tax liability. But after several years the deductibility feature was removed. That action, in the opinion of critics, all but emasculated an otherwise strong incentive to save rather than spend. It probably left a legacy of doubt about government promised that could impact the Family Savings Plans. However, some of the other tax changes in recent years have been more in line with the need to save rather than spend. Most consumer debt, for example, no longer is tax deductible, thus removing at least one incentive to spending. Americans accepted that action with amazing calmness, even though it proved to be enormously costly to them. However, it didn't stop them from taking on debt, and in that respect it failed to make a dent in the buy-now philosophy. It leaves this question: If people feel so strongly about buying that they will pay higher taxes in order to continue buying, will a program that rewards them for savings instead of buying be any more successful?
